prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Imaging the bright [CII] emission in a z=6.8 quasar host
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: The goal of these observations is to obtain deep, high resolution (0.17") images of a z=6.8 quasar host in both [CII] emission and the FIR dust continuum.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The [CII] line in the host of quasar J0109-3047 at z=6.791 has already been detected with a line flux of 1.23 Jy km/s and a FWHM of 340 km/s (Fig. 1). To accurate map the emission over several beams and detect broad emission signatures, we need to image the line at high S/N (>30 sigma; see e.g. Walter et al. 2003; Maiolino et al. 2012; Wang et al. 2013) and at high spatial resolution.
ALMA provides a resolution of 0.17" (configuration C34-7) at the frequency of the [CII] line. This resolution corresponds to scales of ~0.9 kpc at the quasar's redshift. Observations at this resolution will allow us to resolve star formation of scales around a kpc. An extended star burst on similar scales has been observed in the z=6.4 quasar host J1148+5251 (Walter et al. 2009). We note that we already have short spacing information from our Cycle 1 observations.
The average line flux over the FWHM is 3.6 mJy. To reach the required S/N, we need to obtain an rms of 0.12 mJy over a bandwidth of 340 km/s. According to the sensitivity calculator in the ALMA OT, we need an on-source exposure time of 34.4 minutes. Simultaneously, this will yield an rms of 0.033 mJy in the continuum (two spectral windows (see below), total bandwidth of 3.7 GHz). With the continuum around the [CII] line having an observed flux density of ~0.7 mJy (Fig. 1), the FIR emission will also be detected with a S/N>20, i.e. the emission can be resolved easily.
The sensitivity calculator in the ALMA OT estimates that the total overheads (including calibrations) are 41.3 minutes, so for this science goal we request a total of 75.7 minutes of 12m array time.
The coarsest spectral resolution that is available results in a bandwidth of the spectral window of 1.875 GHz. This corresponds to ~2300 km/s at the frequency of the redshifted [CII] line. Since one of the aims of the observations is to look for high velocity inflowing or outflowing gas, we will observe the line in two partly overlapping spectral windows. With a conservative 20% overlap we will map a total of 4100 km/s around the [CII] line. The two remaining spectral windows will be used to map the continuum around 168 micron in the quasar's rest-frame. Since the [CII] line is broad (FWHM=340 km/s), we will apply a spectral averaging over 8 channels, resulting in spectral resolution of ~5 km/s and a data rate of <3 MB/s.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Imaging the bright [CII] emission in a z=6.6 quasar host
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: The goal of these observations is to obtain deep, high resolution (0.17") images of a z=6.6 quasar host in both [CII] emission and the FIR dust continuum.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The [CII] line in the host of quasar J0305-3150 at z=6.615 has already been detected with a line flux of 1.59 Jy km/s and a FWHM of 250 km/s (Fig. 1). To accurate map the emission over several beams and detect broad emission signatures, we need to image the line at high S/N (>30 sigma; see e.g. Walter et al. 2003; Maiolino et al. 2012; Wang et al. 2013) and at high spatial resolution.
ALMA provides a resolution of 0.17" (configuration C34-7) at the frequency of the [CII] line. This resolution corresponds to scales of ~0.9 kpc at the quasar's redshift. Observations at this resolution will allow us to resolve star formation of scales around a kpc. An extended star burst on similar scales has been observed in the z=6.4 quasar host J1148+5251 (Walter et al. 2009). We note that we already have short spacing information from our Cycle 1 observations.
The average line flux over the FWHM is 6.4 mJy. To reach the required S/N, we need to obtain an rms of 0.21 mJy over a bandwidth of 250 km/s. According to the sensitivity calculator in the ALMA OT, we need an on-source exposure time of 14.7 minutes. Simultaneously, this will yield an rms of 0.05 mJy in the continuum (two spectral windows (see below), total bandwidth of 3.7 GHz). With the continuum around the [CII] line having an observed flux density of ~2.4 mJy (Fig. 1), the FIR emission will also be detected with a S/N>45, i.e. the emission can be resolved easily.
The sensitivity calculator in the ALMA OT estimates that the total overheads (including calibrations) are 30.0 minutes, so for this science goal we request a total of 46.7 minutes of 12m array time.
The coarsest spectral resolution that is available results in a bandwidth of the spectral window of 1.875 GHz. This corresponds to ~2200 km/s at the frequency of the redshifted [CII] line. Since one of the aims of the observations is to look for high velocity inflowing or outflowing gas, we will observe the line in two partly overlapping spectral windows. With a conservative 20% overlap we will map a total of 4000 km/s around the [CII] line. The two remaining spectral windows will be used to map the continuum around 168 micron in the quasar's rest-frame. Since the [CII] line is broad (FWHM=250 km/s), we will apply a spectral averaging over 8 channels, resulting in spectral resolution of ~5 km/s, and a data rate of <3 MB/s.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Imaging the bright [CII] emission in a z=6.9 quasar host
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: The goal of these observations is to obtain deep, high resolution (0.17") images of a z=6.9 quasar host in both [CII] emission and the FIR dust continuum.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The [CII] line in the host of quasar J2348-3054 at z=6.904 has already been detected with a line flux of 1.48 Jy km/s and a FWHM of 530 km/s (Fig. 1). To accurate map the emission over several beams and detect broad emission signatures, we need to image the line at high S/N (>30 sigma; see e.g. Walter et al. 2003; Maiolino et al. 2012; Wang et al. 2013) and at high spatial resolution.
ALMA provides a resolution of 0.17" (configuration C34-7) at the frequency of the [CII] line. This resolution corresponds to scales of ~0.9 kpc at the quasar's redshift. Observations at this resolution will allow us to resolve star formation of scales around a kpc. An extended star burst on similar scales has been observed in the z=6.4 quasar host J1148+5251 (Walter et al. 2009). We note that we already have short spacing information from our Cycle 1 observations.
The average line flux over the FWHM is 2.8 mJy. To reach the required S/N, we need to obtain an rms of 0.09 mJy over a bandwidth of 530 km/s. According to the sensitivity calculator in the ALMA OT, we need an on-source exposure time of 35.5 minutes. Simultaneously, this will yield an rms of 0.032 mJy in the continuum (two spectral windows (see below), total bandwidth of 3.7 GHz). With the continuum around the [CII] line having an observed flux density of ~1.7 mJy (Fig. 1), the FIR emission will also be detected with a S/N>50, i.e. the emission can be resolved easily.
The sensitivity calculator in the ALMA OT estimates that the total overheads (including calibrations) are 41.3 minutes, so for this science goal we request a total of 76.8 minutes of 12m array time.
The coarsest spectral resolution that is available results in a bandwidth of the spectral window of 1.875 GHz. This corresponds to ~2300 km/s at the frequency of the redshifted [CII] line. Since one of the aims of the observations is to look for high velocity inflowing or outflowing gas, we will observe the line in two partly overlapping spectral windows. With a conservative 20% overlap we will map a total of 4100 km/s around the [CII] line. The two remaining spectral windows will be used to map the continuum around 168 micron in the quasar's rest-frame. Since the [CII] line is broad (FWHM=530 km/s), we will apply a spectral averaging over 8 channels, resulting in spectral resolution of ~5 km/s, and a data rate of <3 MB/s.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Measuring the CO and CI emission in a z=6.8 quasar host
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: The goal of these short, low resolution Band 3 observations is to detect the CO(6-5), CO(7-6) and CI emission lines in a quasar host at z=6.8

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The goal of these low resolution Band 3 observations of J0109-3047 at z=6.791 is to measure the strength of the CO(6-5), CO(7-6) and CI emission lines in a single frequency setup. Since the goal of the observations is to detect the line, we do not require high spatial resolution and the observations can be executed using any configuration. In combination with the relaxed weather constraints, these Band 3 observations are ideal as a filler / bad weather project.
The quasar has rest-frame UV properties (De Rosa et al. 2013), [CII] line strength and FIR luminosity (Fig. 1) comparable to z~6 SDSS quasars that have been successfully detected with the PdBI, VLA and ALMA in CO and [CII] emission (published in e.g. Walter et al. 2003, 2004, 2011; Carilli et al. 2007; Wang et al. 2010, 2011, 2013). We therefore assume the properties of the CO lines in this quasar host are similar to the observed SDSS ones.
To compute the expected line strength, we assume that the width of the CO line will be similar to that of the [CII] line. In the following we will therefore adopt a FWHM of the CO line of 340 km/s. For quasars at z~6 with similar properties as J0109-3047, the typical (median) observed CO(6-5) line strength is 0.5 Jy km/s (with a non-negligible scatter of +/-0.2 Jy km/s), see e.g. the compilation by Wang et al. (2010). Observations and modelling of the CO excitation ladder of the quasar J1148+5251 at z=6.42 and other high redshift quasars show that the CO(7-6)/CO(6-5) line ratio is ~1 (e.g. Bertoldi et al. 2003b; Riechers et al. 2009). This means that we expect a line strength of ~0.5 Jy km/s for both the CO(6-5) and CO(7-6) lines in J0109-3047. To detect such a line with a S/N of 8, we need to reach ~0.18 mJy in a bandwidth of 340 km/s. The ALMA Observing Tool indicates that this sensitivity can be reached in 22.4 minutes of on-source observations.
The CI line is likely fainter by a factor of ~few (e.g. Riechers et al. 2009; Walter et al. 2011), so there is good chance that the line will be detected with the proposed observations. Even a non-detection of the CI line will provide powerful constraints on the density and radiation field in the interstellar medium in the host galaxy (see Fig. 3).
The sensitivity calculator in the ALMA OT estimates that the total overheads (including calibrations) are 31.4 minutes, so for this science goal we request a total of 53.8 minutes of 12m array time.
The spectral setup is carefully tuned in order to simultaneously observe the CO(6-5), CO(7-6) and CI lines. Thanks to the very accurate redshift of the quasar host galaxy from our [CII] observations (Fig. 1), we can be very certain about the location of the lines in frequency space. Using the coarsest spectral resolution (resulting in a bandwidth of the spectral windows of 1.875 GHz), we placed one spectral window around the CO(6-5) line and a second spectral window around the CO(7-6) and CI lines. We made sure that the lines were >>1000 km/s (at least 5 times the dispersion of the [CII] line) away from the edges of the spectral windows. The two other spectral windows, with a bandwidth of 1.875 GHz each, are employed to measure the continuum flux around 400 micron in the quasar's rest-frame.
Since we expect the emission lines to be broad with a FWHM of 340 km/s, we will apply a spectral averaging over 8 channels, resulting in a spectral resolution of ~12-13 km/s and a data rate of <3 MB/s.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Measuring the CO and CI emission in a z=6.6 quasar host
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: The goal of these short, low resolution Band 3 observations is to detect the CO(6-5), CO(7-6) and CI emission lines in a quasar host at z=6.6

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The goal of these low resolution Band 3 observations of J0305-3150 at z=6.615 is to measure the strength of the CO(6-5), CO(7-6) and CI emission lines in a single frequency setup. Since the goal of the observations is to detect the lines, we do not require high spatial resolution and the observations can be executed using any configuration. In combination with the relaxed weather constraints, these Band 3 observations are ideal as a filler / bad weather project.
The quasar has rest-frame UV properties (De Rosa et al. 2013), [CII] line strength and FIR luminosity (Fig. 1) comparable to SDSS z~6 quasars that have been successfully detected with the PdBI, VLA and ALMA in CO and [CII] emission (published in e.g. Walter et al. 2003, 2004, 2011; Carilli et al. 2007; Wang et al. 2010, 2011, 2013). We therefore assume the properties of the CO lines in this quasar host are similar to the observed SDSS ones.
To compute the expected line strength, we assume that the width of the CO line will be similar to that of the [CII] line. In the following we will therefore adopt a FWHM of the CO line of 250 km/s. For quasars at z~6 with similar properties as J0305-3150, the typical (median) observed CO(6-5) line strength is 0.5 Jy km/s (with a non-negligible scatter of +/-0.2 Jy km/s), see e.g. the compilation by Wang et al. (2010). Observations and modelling of the CO excitation ladder of the quasar J1148+5251 at z=6.42 and other high redshift quasars show that the CO(7-6)/CO(6-5) line ratio is ~1 (e.g. Bertoldi et al. 2003b; Riechers et al. 2009). This means that we expect a line strength of ~0.5 Jy km/s for both the CO(6-5) and CO(7-6) lines in J0305-3150. To detect such a line with a S/N of 8, we need to reach ~0.25 mJy in a bandwidth of 250 km/s. The ALMA Observing Tool indicates that this sensitivity can be reached in 15.5 minutes of on-source observations.
The CI line is likely fainter by a factor of ~few (e.g. Riechers et al. 2009; Walter et al. 2011), so there is good chance that the line will be detected with the proposed observations. Even a non-detection of the CI line will provide powerful constraints on the density and radiation field in the interstellar medium in the host galaxy (see Fig. 3).
The sensitivity calculator in the ALMA OT estimates that the total overheads (including calibrations) are 28.5 minutes, so for this science goal we request a total of 43.9 minutes of 12m array time.
The spectral setup is carefully tuned in order to simultaneously observe the CO(6-5), CO(7-6) and CI lines. Thanks to the very accurate redshift of the quasar host galaxy from our [CII] observations (Fig. 1), we can be very certain about the location of the lines in frequency space. Using the coarsest spectral resolution (resulting in a bandwidth of the spectral windows of 1.875 GHz), we placed one spectral window around the CO(6-5) line and a second spectral window around the CO(7-6) and CI lines. We made sure that the lines were >>500 km/s (at least 5 times the dispersion of the [CII] line) away from the edges of the spectral windows. The two other spectral windows, with a bandwidth of 1.875 GHz each, are employed to measure the continuum flux around 400 micron in the quasar's rest-frame.
Since we expect the emission lines to be broad with a FWHM of 250 km/s, we will apply a spectral averaging over 8 channels, resulting in a spectral resolution of ~12-13 km/s and a data rate of <3 MB/s.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Measuring the CO and CI emission in a z=6.9 quasar host
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: The goal of these short, low resolution Band 3 observations is to detect the CO(6-5), CO(7-6) and CI emission lines in a quasar host at z=6.9

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The goal of these low resolution Band 3 observations of J2348-3054 at z=6.904 is to measure the strength of the CO(6-5), CO(7-6) and CI emission lines in a single frequency setup. Since the goal of the observations is to detect the lines, we do not require high spatial resolution and the observations can be executed using any configuration. In combination with the relaxed weather constraints, these Band 3 observations are ideal as a filler / bad weather project.
The quasar has rest-frame UV properties (De Rosa et al. 2013), [CII] line strength and FIR luminosity (Fig. 1) comparable to z~6 SDSS quasars that have been successfully detected with the PdBI, VLA and ALMA in CO and [CII] emission (published in e.g. Walter et al. 2003, 2004, 2011; Carilli et al. 2007; Wang et al. 2010, 2011, 2013). To compute the expected line strength, we assume that the width of the CO line will be similar to that of the [CII] line. In the following we will therefore adopt a FWHM of the CO line of 530 km/s. For quasars at z~6 with similar properties as J2348-3054, the typical (median) observed CO(6-5) line strength is 0.5 Jy km/s (with a non-negligible scatter of +/-0.2 Jy km/s), see e.g. the compilation by Wang et al. (2010). This means that we expect a line strength of ~0.5 Jy km/s for both the CO(6-5) and CO(7-6) lines in J2348-3054. To detect such a line with a S/N of 8, we need to reach ~0.12 mJy in a bandwidth of 530 km/s. The ALMA Observing Tool indicates that this sensitivity can be reached in 32.8 minutes of on-source observations.
The CI line is likely fainter by a factor of ~few (e.g. Riechers et al. 2009; Walter et al. 2011), so there is good chance that the line will be detected with the proposed observations. Even a non-detection of the CI line will provide powerful constraints on the density and radiation field in the interstellar medium in the host galaxy (see Fig. 3).
The sensitivity calculator in the ALMA OT estimates that the total overheads (including calibrations) are 34.5 minutes, so for this science goal we request a total of 67.3 minutes of 12m array time.
The spectral setup is carefully tuned in order to simultaneously observe the CO(6-5), CO(7-6) and CI lines. Thanks to the very accurate redshift of the quasar host galaxy from our [CII] observations (Fig. 1), we can be very certain about the location of the lines in frequency space. Using the coarsest spectral resolution (resulting in a bandwidth of the spectral windows of 1.875 GHz), we placed one spectral window around the CO(6-5) line and a second spectral window around the CO(7-6) and CI lines. We made sure that the lines were >>1500 km/s (at least 5 times the dispersion of the [CII] line) away from the edges of the spectral windows. The two other spectral windows, with a bandwidth of 1.875 GHz each, are employed to measure the continuum flux around 400 micron in the quasar's rest-frame.
Since we expect the emission lines to be broad with a FWHM of 530 km/s, we will apply a spectral averaging over 8 channels, resulting in a spectral resolution of ~12-13 km/s and a data rate of <3 MB/s.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: High redshift quasars are likely hosted by the most massive and luminous galaxies in the early universe. We discovered four bright quasars at 6.6<z<7.1, providing a unique opportunity to study massive galaxies at z~7. Our low resolution ALMA Cycle 1 and PdBI observations already revealed strong [CII] emission and far-infrared (FIR) continua in these sources. Here we propose to obtain deep followup observations at sub-kiloparsec resolution (~0.17", ~0.9 kpc at z~7) to address key aspects that cannot be answered with the available data. In only ~30 min (on-source) we will be able to (1) constrain the morphology and kinematics of the emission line gas, (2) produce a map of the star formation as traced by the FIR, (3) look for a possible recent merger event, (4) search for infall/outflow signatures and (5) derive an improved dynamical mass. Complementing this, we request low resolution Band 3 observations that will cover the CO(6-5), CO(7-6) and CI emission lines in a single setup. Combined with the [CII] line, these observations will provide unique constraints on the molecular gas mass, star formation, the density and radiation field in the earliest accessible systems in the universe.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Institute of Astronomy, Cambridge, University of
